Authors: László G. Nagy, Csaba Vágvölgyi, Tamás Papp
Title:
A multi-gene phylogeny and morphological evolution of the
Psathyrellaceae (Agaricales)
Keywords:
Basidiomycetes, deliquescence, taxonomy, classification,
MCMC convergence, Bayesian mixture model
Abstract:
The phylogeny of the Psathyrellaceae is a hot topic in
fungal evolutionary studies. Despite repeated efforts for inferring
stable trees that can serve as a basis for reclassification of the
family, extensive taxonomic rearrangements have been withheld by several
factors, among others, inadequate taxon sampling in several clades and
low support values. There is a general consensus that a comprehensive,
well-sampled phylogeny is needed for the family. In this paper we
present a well-resolved, robust phylogeny and morphological definitions
for the clades we recovered. Sequence data from four nuclear genes
(approximately 4.7 kb) and various phylogenetic methods were used to
infer relationships and analyze various types of uncertainties
associated with our Bayesian estimates. Special attention has been paid
to branch length priors, convergence and their effects on clade
posteriors. Unexpected relationships and other morphologically informed
phylogenetic hypotheses have been tested by constraint analyses. Nearly
fully resolved consensus trees have been obtained with strong support
for most of the large nodes and several early evolutionary events. We
found that obtaining realistic branch length estimates necessitated
adjustments to the default priors and that comparison of different
methods can reveal more of the underlying phylogenetic uncertainty than
nodal support values obtained from a single analysis due to matters of
convergence and mixing for the MCMC analyses. Further, we proved that,
support values and topologies are very slightly or not affected in our
data set and that overestimation of branch lengths caused by prior
misspecification affects branches of different lengths proportionally.
Altogether, 14 major clades of the Psathyrellaceae have been recovered
and characterized by morphological traits. We identified poorly sampled
regions of the phylogeny and discuss potential additions and extensions
of the phylogeny. Prospects for and potential pitfalls of a future
reclassification are discussed in detail.
